thread.title: NYC's homeless crisis may cost $200M more next year, report says
thread.title_full: NYC's homeless crisis may cost $200M more next year, report says

author: ERIN DURKIN
title: NYC's homeless crisis may cost $200M more next year, report says
text:
NYC's homeless shelter crisis may cost $200M more than Mayor de Blasio's proposed budget, report says NYC's homeless crisis may cost $200M more next year, report says NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  26 PM 
The city will have to shell out nearly $200 million more on homeless shelters next year on top of what’s in Mayor de Blasio’s budget, according to a report by an independent budget watchdog. 
Taxpayers are spending $1.7 billion in the current fiscal year on the Department of Homeless Services — after twice injecting extra cash totaling $287 million beyond what was in the city budget passed in June to deal with the burgeoning homeless crisis. 
Nonetheless, de Blasio’s preliminary budget released last month predicts spending will drop by $257 million next year, to $1.4 billion, in 2018. 
The Independent Budget Office said in a report released Wednesday that isn’t going to happen. 
NYC to stop using nonprofit cited for run-down homeless housing 
“Continued increases in the cost of sheltering the city’s homeless population is likely to be the norm over the next few years,” IBO says in the report. 
Next year’s budget is low-balled by about $190 million in de Blasio’s proposal, they project. The majority of new funds will be needed for single adult shelters. 
The $1.7 billion budget for DHS this year represents a 20% jump from the year before. Most of that, $1.4 billion, goes directly to shelter capacity. 
City officials say they know they’ll likely have to spend more, but are waiting until de Blasio releases a long-promised homelessness plan in coming weeks. A revised figure will be in the mayor’s executive budget in the spring. There are 60,048 people living in city shelters as of this Monday. The population crossed the 60,000 mark for the first time ever in the fall. (Spencer Platt/Getty Images) 
“We will be releasing a comprehensive plan outlining our commitment to homeless New Yorkers in greater detail, including new investments,” said DHS spokesman Isaac McGinn. “That’s on top of our tenfold increase in funding for legal services, a 24% drop in evictions, an 83% reduction in violations in shelters, nearly 700 individuals helped off the streets through our HOME-STAT program, and secured permanent housing for 51,000 men, women, and children.” 
There are 60,048 people living in city shelters as of this Monday. The population crossed the 60,000 mark for the first time ever in the fall. 
Shelter spending comes out to about $23,300 per person. 
Homeless spending has surged in part because the city is using expensive commercial hotels to house homeless families, according to IBO. De Blasio has vowed to phase out the practice, but it continues to be widespread. 
Child abuse cases, homelessness on rise in NYC, de Blasio reports 
When spending related to homelessness from agencies outside DHS is counted, the city is spending $2.3 billion this year on the issue, City Controller Scott Stringer said last week. 
By comparison, the 2017 budget is $4.9 billion for the NYPD, $1.8 billion for the FDNY, and $11 billion for the Department of Education. Tags:
